Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: DIAGNOSIS AND PROGNOSIS OF AUTOMOTIVE CHASSIS SYSTEMS

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed collaborative project with GM R&D center, Warren, MI seeks to develop hybrid model-based/data-driven/knowledge-based prognostic framework, and the associated prediction and inference algorithms, to detect and isolate incipient component degradations in coupled systems. The focus will be on chassis health determination (meaning the health status of steering, braking and suspension components, as well as functionalities that use these components such as the StabiliTrak system) to replaceable components (e.g., broken tie rod, worn out brake pads or blown tire, malfunctioning ABS control module). The diagnostic and prognostic framework will be validated on test fleet prior to implementing in the production versions.

Intellectual Merit: Existing prognostic and diagnostic algorithms employed in automotive systems tend to be component-centric. They often fail to provide correct diagnosis due to neglect of cross-subsystem failure propagation and unreliable tests. The proposed research seeks to overcome these limitations by explicitly modeling the cross-subsystem effects via a graphical model and by developing a multi-layer probabilistic reasoning process spanning sensed data → predicted features → diagnostic trouble codes → failure modes → replaceable components and subsystems. Modeling the time evolution of coupled component states as factorial hidden Markov models and the development of computationally-efficient inference algorithms in multi-layer graphical models is a novel aspect of the proposed effort. In addition, combining model-based, data-driven and knowledge-based approaches in a unified way to solve practical diagnosis and prognosis problems in the next-generation automotive vehicles is another contribution of this work.

Broader Impact: The proposed research improves the competitiveness of American automotive industry by reducing warranty costs, and enhancing vehicle availability and customer satisfaction. The PI plans to promulgate the results of this research to the broader industrial community via short courses, tutorials, conference presentations and journal manuscripts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in sensor technology, remote communication and computational capabilities, and standardized hardware/software interfaces are creating a dramatic shift in the way the health of vehicles is monitored and managed. There is also an increased trend towards the forecasting of system degradation through a prognostic process, since conventional maintenance strategies, such as corrective and preventive maintenance, are not adequate to fulfill the needs of customers demanding high vehicle availability. Failure prognosis involves forecasting of system degradation and time-to-failure based on “state awareness” gleaned from monitored data (e.g., vehicle speed, individual wheel speeds, yaw rate, master brake cylinder pressure). Prognosis is viewed as an add-on capability to diagnosis; it assesses the current health of a system and predicts its remaining useful life based on sensed features that capture the gradual degradation in the vehicle operation. Predictive capability is critical for improving safety, scheduling maintenance, and reducing operational and warranty costs.

In this project, we developed a) an integrated model-based/data-driven/knowledge-based prognostic framework; b) the associated fault models in vehicle systems; and c) inference algorithms to detect and isolate incipient component degradations in coupled systems. The integrated diagnostic and prognostic framework is shown in Fig. 1. For prognosis, we investigated a novel multiple model moving horizon estimation algorithm to predict the survival functions of components based on their usage profiles and validated it using field data derived from an automotive electronic throttle control system. A complex automotive chassis system may experience multiple faults that evolve over time; we developed a dynamic set covering algorithm to evaluate the most likely evolution of the component fault states covering the failed tests at minimum cost. We also investigated the problem of diagnosing dependent faults with propagation and observation delays in the presence of imperfect diagnostic codes using coupled factorial hidden Markov models and delay dynamic coupled fault diagnosis models. We proposed a new formulation for the problem of optimal test selection for fault detection and isolation when the tests are imperfect.  

The diverse nature of this project helped students develop a strong understanding of automotive system models for fault diagnosis, in particular the chassis system, different simulation tools, system failure modes, designing tests for anomaly detection, and diagnostic and prognostic methodologies. The students also gained hands-on experience in devising creative solutions (using tools, e.g., MATLAB/SIMULINK, CarSim, VehicleSpy, etc.) to difficult diagnosis problems in this domain. The students worked closely with the engineers and research scientists from GM R&D in acquiring automotive domain expertise and gained valuable practical experience through discussions and internships. Four PhD students had the opportunity to interact with the GM R&D Vehicle Health Management (VHM) group in Warren, Michigan through summer internships funded by GM. These internships enhanced their knowledge of state-of-the-art automotive technologies, diagnostic and prognostic methodologies and condition-based maintenance (CBM) strategies, primarily for electronic return-less fuel system and stop-start starter subsystem, including hands-on expertise in a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) test bench setup, conducting HIL simulations, fault injection and data acquisition from actual vehicles. Two of the students were hired as full-time employees by GM.
